{{globalize|date=February 2014}} '''Commentary on Edward Snowden's disclosure''' is part of the [[reactions to global surveillance disclosures]] made by [[Edward Snowden]].
==Executive branch== On June 8, 2013, [[Director of National Intelligence]] (DNI) [[James R. Clapper]] denounced as "reckless" the disclosures of "intelligence community measures used to keep Americans safe."<ref name="probereq">{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/09/us-usa-security-clapper-idUSBRE9570GL20130609 |title= Spy agency seeks criminal probe into leaks |last1=Gardner |first1=Timothy |first2=Mark |last2=Hosenball |date=June 9, 2013 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> He condemned the leaks as having done "huge, grave damage" to the U.S. intelligence capabilities.<ref name="washclapper">{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/09/clapper-leaks-are-literally-gut-wrenching-leaker-being-sought/ |title=Clapper: Leaks are 'literally gut-wrenching,' leaker being sought |first1=Aaron |last1=Blake |date=June 9, 2013 |accessdate=August 8, 2013 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
Later that month, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] was dismissive of Snowden, saying, "I'm not going to be scrambling jets to get a 29-year-old hacker."<ref>{{cite news|title=Obama downplays Snowden case, says US not 'scrambling jets' to get 'hacker'|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/06/27/obama-downplays-snowden-case-says-us-not-scrambling-jets-to-get-hacker/|newspaper=Fox News|date=June 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pecquet|first=Julian|title=US won't 'scramble jets' to capture 'hacker' Snowden, Obama says|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/global-affairs/africa/308117-obama-wont-scramble-jets-to-capture-hacker-snowden|newspaper=The Hill|date=June 27, 2013}}</ref> In early August, Obama said that Snowden was no patriot and that Americans would have been better off if they had remained unaware of the NSA surveillance activities that Snowden revealed.<ref name=CNN081313>{{cite news|last=Wolf|first=Z. Byron|title=Fact-checking Obama's claims about Snowden|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/08/12/politics/obama-snowden-whistleblower|publisher=CNN|date=August 13, 2013}}</ref> Obama also said that he had "called for a thorough review of our surveillance operations before Mr. Snowden made these leaks.... My preference, and I think the American people's preference, would have been for a lawful, orderly examination of these laws; a thoughtful fact-based debate that would then lead us to a better place."<ref name=CNN081313/>
On August 4, [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] [[Martin Dempsey]] said on the weekly ABC interview show ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]]'' that Snowden "has caused us some considerable damage to our intelligence architecture. Our adversaries are changing the way that they communicate."<ref name="ThisWeek">{{cite news |url= http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/video/joint-chiefs-chairman-gen-martin-dempsey-week-19865953. |title=Transcript for Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Martin Dempsey on 'This Week' |date=August 4, 2013 |first=Martha |last=Raddatz |work=ABC News 'This Week' |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
In September, DNI Clapper acknowledged that Snowden may have done a public service and started a needed debate about the balance between privacy and security. "As loath as I am to give any credit for what's happened here, which was egregious, I think it's clear that some of the conversations that this has generated, some of the debate, actually probably needed to happen," he said. "It's unfortunate they didn't happen some time ago, but if there's a good side to this, that's it."<ref>{{cite news|last=Waterman|first=Shaun|title=Congress will rein in NSA's domestic snooping, predicts top U.S. intel official|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/sep/12/us-spy-congress-rein-in-nsa-domestic-snooping/|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Dilanian|first=Ken|title=Clapper: Snowden case brings healthy debate; more disclosures to come|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-clapper-snowden-disclosures-20130912,0,7438979.story|accessdate=September 15, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref>
On January 29, 2014, DNI Clapper gave public testimony to a session of the Senate Intelligence Committee. He asked that "Snowden and his accomplices" return the purloined NSA documents. When Clapper was asked whether the word "accomplices" referred to journalists, Clapper's spokesperson Shawn Turner responded, "Director Clapper was referring to anyone who is assisting Edward Snowden to further threaten our national security through the unauthorized disclosure of stolen documents related to lawful foreign intelligence collection programs."<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/29/james-clapper-condemns-snowden-senate-testimony |title=James Clapper calls for Snowden and 'accomplices' to return NSA documents |last=Ackerman |first=Spencer |date=2014-01-29 |newspaper=The Guardian }}</ref>
===Former executive branch officials=== In late June 2013, Former US President [[Jimmy Carter]] said: "He's obviously violated the laws of America, for which he's responsible, but I think the invasion of human rights and American privacy has gone too far ... I think that the secrecy that has been surrounding this invasion of privacy has been excessive, so I think that the bringing of it to the public notice has probably been, in the long term, beneficial."<ref>Watkins, Tom (June 30, 2013). [http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/28/us/snowden-lawyer-offer "Father proposes deal for Snowden's voluntary return"], CNN</ref>
Earlier that month, former Vice President [[Dick Cheney]] suggested that Snowden might be a spy working for the Chinese government.<ref>{{cite web|title=Edward Snowden is a 'traitor' and possible spy for China – Dick Cheney|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/16/nsa-whistleblower-edward-snowden-traitor-cheney|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref>
Some former U.S. intelligence officials speculated that Chinese or Russian intelligence agents might have gleaned additional classified material from Snowden,<ref>Schindler, John R. (June 27, 2013). [http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/snowden-the-us-russian-spywar-8668 "Snowden in the U.S.-Russian 'SpyWar'"]. ''[[National Affairs]]''.</ref><ref>Ross, Brian (June 26, 2013). [http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/edward-snowden-steps-secret-us-russia-spy-scuffle/story?id=19495341 "Edward Snowden Steps Into Secret U.S.-Russia Spy Scuffle"]. ''[[ABC News]]''</ref><ref>Ewing, Philip (June 25, 2013). [http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/edward-snowden-foreign-intel-93366.html "What Russian intel might ask Edward Snowden"]. ''[[Politico]]''.</ref> a view shared by some former Russian agents.<ref>Simon Schuster (July 10, 2013). [http://world.time.com/2013/07/10/snowden-in-moscow-what-are-russian-authorities-doing-with-the-nsa-whistleblower/ Snowden in Moscow: What Russian Authorities Might Be Doing With the NSA Whistle-Blower] ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''</ref> Snowden, however, told journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]] in July, "I never gave any information to either government, and they never took anything from my laptops."<ref name="GuardianJuly10">[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/10/snowden-denies-information-russia-china Snowden: I never gave any information to Chinese or Russian governments], Glenn Greenwald, July 10, 2013</ref>
[[Stewart Baker]], a former NSA general counsel in the early 1990s, said at a July 18, 2013 hearing, "I am afraid that hyped and distorted press reports orchestrated by Edward Snowden and his allies may cause us – or other nations – to construct new restraints on our intelligence gathering, restraints that will leave us vulnerable to another security disaster."<ref name="wapo717hearing">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/house-committee-holds-hearing-on-nsa-surveillance-programs/2013/07/17/ffc3056c-eee3-11e2-9008-61e94a7ea20d_story.html|title=Lawmakers of both parties voice doubts about NSA surveillance programs|date=July 17, 2013|work=[[The Washington Post]]|first=William|last=Branigin}}</ref>
Former CIA and NSA chief [[General Michael Hayden]] in late June 2013 welcomed the public debate about the balance between privacy and security that the leaks had provoked: "I am convinced the more the American people know exactly what it is we are doing in this balance between privacy and security, the more they know the more comfortable they will feel."<ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/jun/30/former-cia-nsa-chief-michael-hayden-open-spy-progr/ Former CIA, NSA chief Michael Hayden: Open spy programs to reassure U.S. public], ''[[The Washington Times]]'', June 30, 2013. Retrieved Jul 9, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.networkworld.com/community/blog/former-cia-nsa-director-says-give-public-more-info-nsa-surveillance-programs Former CIA, NSA director sounds off on PRISM, spying tools], ''[[Network World]]'', July 1, 2013. Retrieved Jul 9, 2013.</ref> In September 2013, Hayden stressed the indisputable legality of "what the NSA is doing" and called Snowden a "troubled young man", albeit "morally arrogant to a tremendous degree"; he also said about his prospects in Russia: "I suspect he will end up like most of the rest of the defectors who went to the old [[Soviet Union]]: Isolated, bored, lonely, depressed -- and most of them ended up alcoholics."<ref name="snowdenalcoholic">{{cite web|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=Former NSA chief: 'Morally arrogant' Snowden will probably become an alcoholic|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/09/17/former-nsa-chief-morally-arrogant-snowden-will-probably-become-an-alcoholic/?tid=btm_rex_1|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref>
Speaking at the [[University of Connecticut]] on April 23, 2014, former [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] insinuated that she found Snowden's motives suspicious. "When he emerged and when he absconded with all that material, I was puzzled because we have all these protections for whistle-blowers. If he were concerned and wanted to be part of the American debate, he could have been," she said. "But it struck me as—I just have to be honest with you—as sort of odd that he would flee to China, because Hong Kong is controlled by China, and that he would then go to Russia—two countries with which we have very difficult cyberrelationships, to put it mildly." Clinton added, "I think turning over a lot of that material—intentionally or unintentionally—drained, gave all kinds of information, not only to big countries, but to networks and terrorist groups and the like. So I have a hard time thinking that somebody who is a champion of privacy and liberty has taken refuge in Russia, under Putin's authority."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/defense/hillary-clinton-edward-snowden-s-leaks-helped-terrorists-20140425 |title=Hillary Clinton: Edward Snowden's Leaks Helped Terrorists |publisher=NationalJournal.com |date=April 25, 2014}}</ref>
==Congress== Reactions to Snowden's disclosures among members of Congress initially were largely negative.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reeve|first=Elspeth|title=Washington turns on the NSA blinders to target weird 'IT guy' leaker instead|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2013/06/edward-snowden-washington-response/66063/|newspaper=The Atlantic Wire|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> Speaker of the House [[John Boehner]]<ref name=20130611sfchron>{{cite news |title=John Boehner: Edward Snowden Is A 'Traitor' |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=June 11, 2013 |last= LoGiurato |first= Brett |url= http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/JOHN-BOEHNER-Edward-Snowden-Is-A-Traitor-4593261.php |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> and senators [[Dianne Feinstein]]<ref name="thehill.com">{{cite news |last1=Herb |first1=Jeremy |last2=Sink |first2=Justin |title=Sen. Feinstein calls Snowden's NSA leaks an 'act of treason' |publisher=thehill.com |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/defcon-hill/policy-and-strategy/304573-sen-feinstein-snowdens-leaks-are-treason |date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> and [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Bill|title=This man is a traitor|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/man-traitor-article-1.1369682|newspaper=Daily News|location=New York|date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> called Snowden a traitor, and several senators and representatives joined them in calling for Snowden's arrest and prosecution.<ref name="thehill.com"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Edward Snowden: Ex-CIA leaker drops out of sight, faces legal battle |agency=Reuters |work=The Chicago Tribune |date=June 10, 2013 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-06-10/news/chi-edward-snowden-nsa-leaks-20130610_1_u-s-justice-department-regina-ip-hong-kong |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=DNC chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz: Snowden is a coward |first=Aaron|last=Blake|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 11, 2013 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/11/dnc-chair-debbie-wasserman-schultz-snowden-is-a-coward/ |accessdate=June 13, 2013}}</ref>
Representative [[Thomas Massie]] was one of few members of Congress to question the constitutional validity of the government surveillance programs and suggest that Snowden should be granted immunity from prosecution.<ref name="Snowden Has a Few Defenders on the Hill">{{cite news |last1=Dumain |first1=Emma |last2=Lesniewski |first2=Niels |title=Snowden Has a Few Defenders on the Hill |work=Roll Call |url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/snowden_has_a_few_defenders_on_the_hill-225492-1.html?pos=oplyh |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> Senators [[Ted Cruz]]<ref>{{cite news |first=Madeleine |last=Morgenstern |title=Ted Cruz Reserving Judgement on Whether NSA Leaker Is a 'Patriot' or a 'Traitor' |work=The Blaze |date=June 11, 2013 |url= http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2013/06/11/ted-cruz-reserving-judgement-on-whether-nsa-leaker-is-a-patriot-or-a-traitor/ |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> and [[Rand Paul]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Sink|first=Justin|title=Rand Paul 'reserving judgment' on NSA leaker|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/304673-rand-paul-reserving-judgment-on-nsa-leaker|newspaper=The Hill|date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> offered tentative support for Snowden, saying they were reserving judgment on Snowden until more information about the surveillance programs and about Snowden's motives were known. Senator Paul said, "I do think when history looks at this, they are going to contrast the behavior of James Clapper, our National Intelligence Director, with Edward Snowden. Mr. Clapper lied in Congress in defiance of the law, in the name of security. Mr. Snowden told the truth in the name of privacy."<ref>{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Sean|title=Rand Paul: Snowden will face problems if he 'cozies up' to Russia, China|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/23/rand-paul-snowden-will-face-problems-if-he-cozies-up-to-russia-china/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=June 23, 2013}}</ref> Paul later called Snowden a "civil disobedient", like Martin Luther King Jr., but who faced life imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/rand-paul-edward-snowden-nsa-leak-92953.html |title=Rand Paul: Edward Snowden ‘civil disobedient’ – Tal Kopan – |publisher=Politico.com |date=June 18, 2013}}</ref> Representative [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]] made comparisons between Snowden and Gandhi, saying the leaker was appealing to a "higher law".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/08/john-lewis-compares-edward-snowden-gandhi-95317.html |title=John Lewis compares Edward Snowden, Gandhi – James Arkin – |publisher=Politico.com |date=August 8, 2013}}</ref>
Senator [[Bill Nelson (politician)|Bill Nelson]], "What Edward Snowden did amounts to an act of [[treason]]."<ref>{{cite web|title=This man is a traitor|url=http://www.billnelson.senate.gov/news/details.cfm?id=344052&|publisher=senate.gov|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref> Similar comments have also been made by Rep. [[Peter T. King]], Rep. [[John Boehner]], and Sen. [[Dianne Feinstein]].<ref>{{cite web|title=John Boehner: Edward Snowden Is A 'Traitor'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/11/john-boehner-edward-snowden_n_3420635.html|publisher=''The Huffington Post''|accessdate=September 18, 2013}}</ref>
On July 25, the [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|US Senate Committee on Appropriations]] unanimously adopted an amendment by Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] to the "Fiscal Year 2014 Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Appropriations Bill"<ref>{{USBill|113|s|1372|site=yes}}. [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/113/s1372 S. 1372] at [[GovTrack]]. [http://www.opencongress.org/bill/113-s1372/ S. 1372] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203003041/http://www.opencongress.org/bill/113-s1372/ |date=2013-12-03 }} at [[OpenCongress]].</ref> that would seek sanctions against any country that offers asylum to Snowden.<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. lawmakers want sanctions on any country taking in Snowden|first=Patricia|last=Zengerle|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=July 25, 2013|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/25/us-usa-security-congress-idUSBRE96O18220130725}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. Senate advances law pressuring Russia not to give Snowden asylum|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency|Xinhua]]|date=July 26, 2013|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2013-07/26/c_132574418.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite podcast|title=FY14 Full Committee Markup of State-Foreign Operations, and Financial Services General Government Bills|date=July 25, 2013|publisher=[[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations]]|time=1:10:08|url=http://www.appropriations.senate.gov/webcasts.cfm?method=webcasts.view&id=591353fa-8fd0-41e9-9d7e-6adf0ab76537}}</ref>
In response to the information release by Snowden, Rep. [[Justin Amash]] (R-Mich.) and Rep. [[John Conyers]] (D-Mich.) proposed an amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act<ref>{{cite web|author=Max Ehrenfreund |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/house-proposal-to-curtail-nsa-in-response-to-edward-snowdens-leaks-fails-narrowly/2013/07/25/b7117338-f54d-11e2-9434-60440856fadf_story.html |title=House proposal to curtail NSA in response to Edward Snowden's leaks fails narrowly |work=The Washington Post }}</ref> to curtail the NSA gathering and storage of the personal records, but the House rejected it by a narrow margin of 205–217.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2013/07/amash-amendment-fails-despite-democratic-support/67584/ |title=The Amash Amendment Fails, Barely – Abby Ohlheiser and Philip Bump |publisher=The Atlantic Wire |date=July 24, 2013}}</ref> Amash subsequently told [[Fox News]] that Snowden was "a whistle-blower. He told us what we need to know."<ref>{{cite news |title=Amash: Snowden a whistle-blower, 'told us what we need to know' |publisher=Fox News |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/08/04/republican-rep-amash-snowden-whistleblower-told-us-what-need-to-know/ |date=August 4, 2013 |accessdate=October 6, 2013 }}</ref>
On the Sunday ABC interview show ''This Week'', Rep. [[Dutch Ruppersberger]], D-Maryland, of the [[United States House Select Committee on Intelligence]] was asked by Raddatz, "Are efforts being thwarted in trying to get information for members of Congress?" He replied,
<blockquote>...[S]ince this incident occurred with Snowden, we've had three different hearings for members of our Democratic Caucus, and the Republican Caucus, where General Alexander has come with his deputy, Chris Inglis, to ask any questions that people have as it relates to this information. And we will continue to do that because what we're trying to do now is to get the American public to know more about what's going on....But we can do better. I have to educate my caucus more, the Democratic Caucus. And we're trying to declassify as much as we can.<ref name="ThisWeekRuppersberger">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/week-transcript-gen-martin-dempsey-reps-ruppersberger-king/story?id=19864913&page=3. |title='This Week' Transcript: Gen. Martin Dempsey, Reps. Ruppersberger and King, and Glenn Greenwald |date=August 4, 2013 |first=Martha |last=Raddatz |work=ABC News 'This Week' |accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref></blockquote>
U.S. Senator [[John McCain]] (R-AZ) said on the August 11 edition of ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'' that Snowden had become a hero to young Americans, as he reminded them of the [[Jason Bourne]] character. McCain attributed it to generation change and a lack of confidence in the federal government. "Right now there's kind of a generational change," he said. "Young Americans do not trust this government."<ref>{{cite web|title=McCain: Young Americans admire Snowden, see him as ‘some kind of Jason Bourne’|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/aug/11/mccain-young-americans-admire-snowden-see-him-some/|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref>
[[Gordon Humphrey]], the conservative Republican senator for New Hampshire from 1979–1991, expressed support for Snowden.<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Luke|title=Edward Snowden Receives Support From Former GOP Sen. Gordon Humphrey|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/16/edward-snowden-gordon-humphrey_n_3606491.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref> Glenn Greenwald revealed that Humphrey, a former member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had been in contact with Snowden via email. Humphrey told Snowden, "Provided you have not leaked information that would put in harms way any intelligence agent, I believe you have done the right thing in exposing what I regard as massive violation of the United States Constitution."<ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|title=Email exchange between Edward Snowden and former GOP Senator Gordon Humphrey|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/16/gordon-humphrey-email-edward-snowden|work=The Guardian|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref> Humphrey cited Snowden as a "courageous whistle-blower".<ref name=Politico>{{cite web|last=Gold|first=Hadas|authorlink=Hadas Gold|title=Former Sen. Gordon Humphrey emails with Edward Snowden|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/ex-senator-emails-with-snowden-94323.html?hp=f1|publisher=Politico|accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref>
[[Tom McClintock]] (R-Calif) came out in favor of amnesty for Snowden, saying
<blockquote>I think it would be best if the American government granted him amnesty to get him back to America where he can answer questions without the threat of prosecution... We have some very good laws against sharing secrets and he broke those laws. On the other hand, he broke them for a very good reason because those laws were being used in direct contravention of our 4th Amendment rights as Americans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2013/08/12/rep-mcclintock-says-the-us-should-gran |title=Rep. McClintock Says the US Should Grant Snowden Amnesty – Hit & Run |work=Reason|date=July 24, 2013}}</ref></blockquote>
Arizona Senator [[John McCain]] criticized politicians who voted in favor of the PATRIOT Act but were outraged by the NSA spying on phone calls by saying, "We passed the Patriot Act. We passed specific provisions of the act that allowed for this program to take place, to be enacted in operation. Now, if members of Congress did not know what they were voting on, then I think that that's their responsibility a lot more than it is the government's."<ref>http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/06/09/senators-should-have-known-about-snooping-says-mccain/</ref>
==Public== [[Glenn Greenwald]], one of the journalists who received the documents, praised Snowden for having done a service by revealing the surveillance on the American public.<ref name="on-the">{{cite news|first=Glenn |last=Greenwald |authorlink=Glenn Greenwald |date=June 22, 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/22/snowden-espionage-charges |title=On the Espionage Act charges against Edward Snowden |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HaOj8UiN?url=http://www.wusa9.com/rss/article/263548/158/Petition-To-Pardon-Edward-Snowden-Reaches-Goal- |work=The Guardian Security and Liberty blog |location=London |accessdate=June 23, 2013 |archivedate=June 23, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Edward Snowden: Traitor or Hero? |first=Matthew |last=Guariglia |publisher=heavy.com |date=June 10, 2013 |url=http://www.heavy.com/news/2013/06/edward-snowden-hero-traitor-obama/ |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> [[John Cassidy (journalist)|John Cassidy]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' called Snowden "a hero" and said that "in revealing the colossal scale of the US government's eavesdropping on Americans and other people around the world, [Snowden] has performed a great public service that more than outweighs any breach of trust he may have committed."<ref name="Cassidy">{{cite news |last=Cassidy |first=John |date=June 10, 2013 |url= http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/johncassidy/2013/06/why-edward-snowden-is-a-hero.html |title=Why Edward Snowden Is A Hero |work=The New Yorker}}</ref> CNN columnist [[Douglas Rushkoff]] also called Snowden's leak an act of heroism.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/2013/06/10/opinion/rushkoff-snowden-hero/index.html |author=Rushkoff, Douglas |title=Edward Snowden is a hero |accessdate=June 16, 2013 |publisher=CNN |date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> [[Amy Davidson (author)|Amy Davidson]], writing in ''The New Yorker'', was thankful for the "overdue" conversation on privacy and the limits of domestic surveillance.<ref name="NewYorker">{{cite news |last=Davidson |first=Amy |date=June 9, 2013 |url= http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/closeread/2013/06/edward-snowden-the-nsa-leaker-comes-forward.html |title=Edward Snowden, The N.S.A. Leaker, Comes Forward |work=The New Yorker}}</ref>
American political commentators and public figures such as [[Noam Chomsky]],<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/19/nsa-surveillance-attack-american-citizens-noam-chomsky |title=NSA surveillance is an attack on American citizens, says Noam Chomsky |date=June 19, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |location= London |author=Harvey, Fiona |accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref> [[Chris Hedges]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sparrowmedia.net/2013/06/i-stand-with-edward-snowden-rally-union-square/ |title=New Yorkers Declare 'I Stand With Edward Snowden': Dozens Rally & Draw Massive Media Attention for NSA Whistleblower (updated) |date=June 10, 2013 |publisher=the sparrow project |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> [[Michael Moore]],<ref name="Michael Moore/Glenn Beck"/> [[Cornel West]],<ref>{{cite news |url= http://colorlines.com/archives/2013/06/cornell_west_calls_edward_snowden_the_john_brown_of_national_security.html |title=Cornel West Calls Edward Snowden the 'John Brown' of National Security |date= June 28, 2013 |publisher=colorlines |accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref> [[Glenn Beck]],<ref name="Michael Moore/Glenn Beck">{{cite news |last=Gold |first=Hadas |title=Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call Edward Snowden a hero |publisher=[[Politico]] |date=June 10, 2013 |url= http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/edward-snowden-nsa-leak-michael-moore-glenn-beck-92476.html |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> [[Matt Drudge]],<ref name="The Hill Big Brother">{{cite news |last=Budowsky |first=Brent |title=Matt Drudge, Bernie Sanders and Ron Paul versus Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Big Brother |work=The Hill |location =Washington DC |date=June 7, 2013 |url= http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/homeland-security/304147-matt-drudge-bernie-sanders-and-ron-paul-versus-barack-obama-george-w-bush-and-big-brother |accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]], [[Andrew Napolitano]], [[Oliver Stone]],<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/oliver-stone-calls-national-security-agency-secret-leaker-edward-snowden-hero-article-1.1390488 |title=Oliver Stone calls National Security Agency secret-leaker Edward Snowden 'a hero' |date= July 4, 2013}}</ref> [[Michael Savage]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Kirell |first=Andrew |title=Michael Savage Rants Against Fox News' 'Empty Skirts' & 'Lipstick With Legs' For Condemning NSA Leaker |work=Mediaite |date=June 11, 2013 |url= http://www.mediaite.com/tv/michael-savage-rants-against-fox-news-empty-skirts-lipstick-with-legs-for-condemning-nsa-leaker/ |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> and [[Stephen Walt]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Walt |first=Stephen|title=Snowden deserves an immediate presidential pardon|work=Financial Times |date=July 8, 2013 |url= http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/0ccf2d14-e7c1-11e2-babb-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2YUB4jd46|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref> praised Snowden for exposing secret government surveillance.
Other commentators were more critical of Snowden's methods and motivations.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news |last=Reeve |first=Elspeth |title=These Pundits Have Decided Snowden Deserves to Go to Jail |url= http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2013/06/these-pundits-have-decided-snowden-deserves-go-jail/66084/ |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |newspaper=The Atlantic Wire |location= Washington DC |date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> [[Jeffrey Toobin]], for example, denounced Snowden as "a grandiose narcissist who deserves to be in prison."<ref name="toobin">{{cite web|last=Toobin|first=Jeffrey|title=Edward Snowden is no hero|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/comment/2013/06/edward-snowden-nsa-leaker-is-no-hero.html|date=June 10, 2013|work=The New Yorker}}</ref> Writing in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', Toobin argued that the programs exposed were not illegal, therefore Snowden was not a whistleblower. Further, Toobin questioned "whether the government can function when all of its employees (and contractors) can take it upon themselves to sabotage the programs they don’t like".<ref name="toobin"/>
The editors of [[Bloomberg News]] argued that, while the government ought to prosecute Snowden, the media's focus on Snowden took attention away from issues of U.S. government surveillance, the interpretations of the [[Patriot Act]], and the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] (FISA) court actions, all of which are "what really matters in all this."<ref>{{cite news |author=The Editors |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-06-24/this-is-not-about-edward-snowden.html |title=This Is Not About Edward Snowden |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |location=New York |date=June 24, 2013 |accessdate=June 25, 2013}}</ref> Greenwald accused the media in the U.S. of focusing on Edward Snowden instead of on wrongdoing by [[Director of National Intelligence]] [[James R. Clapper]] and other U.S. officials.<ref>[[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]] (July 3, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/03/clapper-lying-snowden-eu-bolivia "James Clapper, EU play-acting, and political priorities"]. ''The Guardian'' Security and Liberty blog (London). Retrieved July 3, 2013.</ref> In an op-ed, author [[Alex Berenson]] argued that the federal government should have flown a representative to Hong Kong to ask Snowden to give testimony in front of the U.S. Congress and offer him a fair criminal trial, with a view to preventing further unintended disclosures of classified information to other countries.<ref>{{cite news |authorlink=Alex Berenson |last=Berenson |first=Alex |date=June 25, 2013 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/25/opinion/snowden-through-the-eyes-of-a-spy-novelist.html?_r=0 |title= Snowden, Through the Eyes of a Spy Novelist |work=The New York Times |accessdate=June 26, 2013}}</ref>
Cybersecurity scholar [[P. W. Singer|Peter Singer]] divided the material disclosed by Snowden into three categories: "smart, useful espionage against enemies of the United States; legally questionable activities that involved US citizens through backdoors and fudging of policy/law; un-strategic (stupid) actions targeting American allies that has had huge blowback on US standing and US business." It was postulated that these were differing ways people viewed Snowden, which could explain why he was so polarizing.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fisher|first=Max|title=The three types of NSA snooping that Edward Snowden revealed|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/01/03/the-three-types-of-nsa-snooping-that-edward-snowden-revealed/|accessdate=January 4, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=January 3, 2014}}</ref> Singer also spoke of a "double legacy" from the NSA revelations released by Snowden: "One, it's hollowed out the American ability to operate effectively in ensuring the future of the internet itself, in the way we would hope it would be. That has huge long-term consequences. And the second is, it's been and will be a hammer-blow to American technology companies. The cloud computing industry, for example, had a recent estimate that they'll lose $36 billion worth of business because of this."<ref>{{cite news|last=Blogguest|first=TED|title=Obama's 'outside experts' surveillance review panel has deep ties to gov't|url=http://blog.ted.com/2013/11/20/drones-warfare-science-fiction-cybercrime-p-w-singer/|newspaper=TED|date=November 30, 2013}} Drones, warfare, science fiction and cybercrime. A conversation with P.W. Singer</ref>
===Public opinion polls=== Surveys conducted by news outlets and professional polling organizations found that American public opinion was divided on Snowden's disclosures, and that those polled in Canada and Europe were more supportive of Snowden than respondents in the U.S.
====United States==== =====2013===== *June 10–11, 2013: [[Gallup Poll|Gallup]] poll showed 44 percent of Americans thought it was right for Snowden to share the information with the press while 42 percent thought it was wrong.<ref name="Gallup">{{cite news |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/163043/americans-disapprove-government-surveillance-programs.aspx|title=Americans Disapprove of Government Surveillance Programs|newspaper=Gallup|first= Frank |last=Newport|date=June 12, 2013}}</ref> *June 12–16: ''[[USA Today]]''/[[Pew Research]] poll found that 49 percent thought the release of information served the public interest while 44 percent thought it harmed it. The same poll found that 54 percent felt a criminal case should be brought against Snowden, and 38 percent disagreed.<ref name="Pew">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.people-press.org/2013/06/17/public-split-over-impact-of-nsa-leak-but-most-want-snowden-prosecuted/ |title=Public Split over Impact of NSA Leak, But Most Want Snowden Prosecuted |publisher=Pew Research Center |date=June 17, 2013 }}</ref> *June 12–16: ''[[The Washington Post]]''-[[ABC News]] poll cited 43 percent of respondents saying Snowden ought to be charged with a crime, while 48 percent said he ought not.<ref name="WaPoPollJune2013">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2013/06/19/poll-public-wants-congressional-hearings-on-nsa-surveillance/ |title=Poll: Public wants congressional hearings on NSA surveillance |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 19, 2013}}</ref> *June 17–18: [[Rasmussen Reports]] asked Americans to describe Snowden in a single word. Twelve percent said he was a hero, 21 percent called him a traitor, 34 percent said he fell somewhere in between, and 29 percent said it was too early to tell.<ref name= RasmussenJun19>{{cite news |url=http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/general_politics/june_2013/12_see_nsa_leaker_snowden_as_hero_21_as_traitor |title=12% See NSA Leaker Snowden As Hero, 21% As Traitor |agency=[[Rasmussen Reports]] |date=June 19, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref> *June 15–July 1: ''[[The Economist]]''/[[YouGov]] poll tracked public opinion over three consecutive weekends, comparing results from June 15–17, June 22–24 and June 29–July 1. Asked their view of Snowden, respondents indicating "favorable" rose from 40 percent to 42 percent then down to 36 percent. "Unfavorable" grew steadily from 39 percent to 41 percent to 43 percent. Those supporting his prosecution increased from 27 percent to 34 percent and held there; those opposed steadily declined from 32 percent to 31 percent to 25 percent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://today.yougov.com/news/2013/07/03/snowden-stays-russia-he-slips-public-opinion/ |title=As Snowden Stays In Russia, He Slips In Public Opinion |agency=[[YouGov]] |date=July 3, 2013}}</ref> *July 1–2: ''[[The Huffington Post]]''/YouGov poll found that 38 percent of Americans thought Snowden did the wrong thing, 33 percent said he did the right thing, and 29 percent were unsure.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Emily Swanson|date=July 5, 2013|title=Edward Snowden Poll Finds More Americans Now Think He Did The Wrong Thing|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/05/edward-snowden-poll_n_3542931.html|newspaper=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=July 9, 2013}}</ref> *July 17–21: [[NBC News]]/''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' Survey found that 11 percent of Americans viewed Snowden positively while 34 percent had a negative view.<ref>Rebecca Ballhaus (July 24, 2013) [https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2013/07/24/wsjnbc-poll-most-americans-view-snowden-negatively/ WSJ/NBC Poll: Most Americans View Snowden Negatively] ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''</ref> *June 28–July 8: [[Quinnipiac University Polling Institute]] survey found that 55 percent of Americans regarded Snowden as a whistleblower while 34 percent saw him as a traitor.<ref name="quinny">{{cite news| author= Salant, Jonathan D.|date=July 10, 2013|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-10/snowden-seen-as-whistlebloweer-by-majority-in-new-poll.html |title=Snowden Seen as Whistle-Blower by Majority in New Poll |newspaper=Bloomberg News|accessdate=July 10, 2013}}</ref> When Quinnipiac repeated the poll from July 28–31, the results were unchanged.<ref>{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Steven|title=As Edward Snowden receives asylum in Russia, poll shows Americans sympathetic to NSA 'whistle-blower'|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/washington-whispers/2013/08/01/edward-snowden-receives-asylum-in-russia-poll-shows-americans-sympathetic-to-nsa-whistle-blower|newspaper=US News & World Report|date=August 1, 2013}}</ref> *July 28–29: Among likely U.S. voters surveyed by Rasmussen Reports, 32 percent considered Snowden a traitor who endangered lives and national security, whereas 11 percent called him a hero.<ref name= RasmussenJun19/> *November 14–17: ''The Washington Post''-ABC News poll found a significant shift in opinion as to whether or not Snowden ought to be charged with a crime. In contrast to the same organizations' June poll, November's results showed 52 percent favoring his prosecution (up from 43 percent) and 38 percent opposed (down from 48 percent). Similarly, when asked whether, irrespective of his being charged with a crime, Snowden was right or wrong to disclose the NSA intelligence-gathering efforts, 37 percent said he was right and 55 percent said he was wrong. All told, nearly two to one (60 percent versus 32 percent) thought Snowden's disclosures had harmed U.S. national security.<ref name="WaPoPollNov2013">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/page/2010-2019/WashingtonPost/2013/11/21/National-Politics/Polling/release_277.xml?uuid=76wqAlJpEeOe5iWACG2CVA |title=Snowden and the NSA - November 2013 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=November 20, 2013}}</ref>
=====2014===== *January 15–19: ''USA Today''/Pew Research poll reported little change from the previous June on the question of the government pursuing a criminal case against Snowden, with 56 percent in favor and 32 percent opposed. The poll found that people younger than 30 offered the least support for prosecution, being evenly divided at 42 percent in favor and 42 percent opposed. Over all age groups, opinion was also nearly equally divided as to whether or not Snowden's disclosures had served the public interest: 45 percent said yes, while 43 percent said Snowden harmed the public interest.<ref name="PewJan2014">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.people-press.org/2014/01/20/obamas-nsa-speech-has-little-impact-on-skeptical-public/ |title=Obama's NSA Speech Has Little Impact on Skeptical Public |publisher=Pew Research Center |date=January 20, 2014}}</ref> *January 18–20: ''The Economist''/YouGov poll likewise found Americans evenly split, with 43 percent viewing Snowden favorably and 41 percent unfavorably; 46 percent approving his leaks and 43 percent disapproving; 28 percent supporting his prosecution and 29 percent opposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Poll Results: Snowden |url=http://today.yougov.com/news/2014/01/22/poll-results-snowden/ |publisher=[[YouGov]] |date=January 22, 2014}}</ref> *January 22: [[CBS News]] poll revealed a larger split (almost 3:1) as to whether or not Snowden ought to stand trial for his actions, with 61 percent in favor and 23 percent saying he should be granted amnesty. CBS News also differed from Pew Research on the issue of whether or not Snowden's disclosures had been good for the country, with 40 percent saying yes and 46 percent saying it had been bad. When asked to come up with a word that best describes Snowden, nearly a quarter of respondents volunteered either "traitor" or a similar word questioning his loyalty to his country, while 8 percent said he is "brave" or "courageous" or "a hero." Just 2 percent volunteered that he is a "patriot" or "patriotic," and another 2 percent said "terrorist."<ref>{{cite web|title=Poll: Most think Edward Snowden should stand trial in U.S. |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/poll-most-think-edward-snowden-should-stand-trial-in-us/|publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=January 22, 2014}}</ref> *January 22–25: NBC News/''The Wall Street Journal'' Survey found continued low public approval for Snowden, with 23 percent supporting what he did, 37 percent opposing it, and 39 percent expressing no opinion.<ref>{{cite web|title=January 2014 NBC News/Wall Street Journal Survey |url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/MSNBC/Sections/A_Politics/_Today_Stories_Teases/14039%20NBC-WSJ%20JANUARY%20POLL%20%281-28%20RELEASE%29.pdf |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=January 22–25, 2014}}</ref> *March 26–28: ''The Huffington Post''/YouGov poll found that 31 percent thought Snowden was right to leak top-secret information about government surveillance programs to the media, while 33 percent believed he was wrong; 45 percent favored his prosecution, with 34 percent opposed; and 35 percent would support a presidential pardon, with 43 percent opposed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://today.yougov.com/news/2014/03/28/poll-results-snowden/ |title=Poll Results: Snowden |agency=[[YouGov]] |date=March 28, 2014}}</ref> *May 20: NBC News asked viewers to weigh in via Twitter on whether they thought Snowden was a "patriot" or "traitor."<ref>{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden: #Traitor or #Patriot |url=http://interactive.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/williams-snowden/?23873&cid=social_nbcnews_main_20140529_24877786 |work=NBC |accessdate=May 31, 2014}}</ref> Prior to airing its Snowden interview, viewers were closely split on the matter; after the program aired, 60 percent said they considered him a patriot.<ref>{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden Is a #Patriot, Twitter Users Say |url=http://mashable.com/2014/05/29/edward-snowden-patriot/ |work=Mashable |accessdate=May 31, 2014}}</ref> *May 29: A YouGov survey found that 55 percent of Americans thought Snowden was right to leak details of the PRISM program. Twenty percent of Americans aged 16–34 thought Snowden's actions were wrong, while 41 percent of those 55 and over held this view.<ref name=DarkReadingYougovMay2014>{{cite web |last=Wilson |first=Tim |title=A Year Later, Most Americans Think Snowden Did The Right Thing |url=http://www.darkreading.com/a-year-later-most-americans-think-snowden-did-the-right-thing/d/d-id/1269269? |work=Dark Reading}}</ref> *June 1: An NBC News poll of registered voters found that 34 percent opposed Snowden's leaks, 24 percent backed him and another 40 percent had no opinion. Among those who closely followed the story, 49 percent opposed his actions and 33 percent supported them. "These overall numbers," said NBC News, "are essentially unchanged from a January 2014 NBC News/Wall Street Journal [poll], when 23 percent of registered voters said they supported Snowden's actions, versus 38 percent who opposed them."<ref name="NBCNews June 1 poll">{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/carbon-combat-obama-begins-battle-over-environmental-regulation-n120171 |title=Carbon Combat: Obama Begins Battle Over Environmental Regulation |first1=Chuck |last1=Todd |first2=Mark |last2=Murray |first3=Carrie |last3=Dann |publisher=NBC News |date=June 2, 2014}}</ref> *July 14: Pew Research Center found worldwide opposition to U.S. eavesdropping and a decline in the view that the U.S. respects its people's personal freedoms, but little evidence that America's overall image had been severely damaged. While the majority of Americans and others condoned spying on suspected terrorists, they agreed it is unacceptable to spy on American citizens.<ref name=PewJuly2014>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2014/07/14/global-opposition-to-u-s-surveillance-and-drones-but-limited-harm-to-americas-image/ |title=Global Opposition to U.S. Surveillance and Drones, but Limited Harm to America's Image |publisher=Pew Research Center |date=July 14, 2014}}</ref>
====Canada and Europe==== In a June 2013 [[Taylor Nelson Sofres|Emnid]] survey, 50 percent of Germans polled considered Snowden a hero, and 35 percent would hide him in their homes.<ref name=NonUShero01a>{{Cite news |first=Valentina |last=Pop |date=July 8, 2013 |title=Germany defends intelligence co-operation with US |url=http://euobserver.com/foreign/120795 |work=[[EUobserver]] |accessdate=July 9, 2013}}</ref>
In October 2013, 67 percent of Canadians polled considered Snowden a hero, as did 60 percent of UK respondents.<ref name=HuffPoHeroTraitor>{{cite news |title=Americans Still Can't Decide Whether Edward Snowden Is A 'Traitor' Or A 'Hero,' Poll Finds |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/30/edward-snowden-poll_n_4175089.html |work=The Huffington Post |accessdate=April 6, 2014 |first=Ariel |last=Edwardslevy |date=October 30, 2013}}</ref>
In an April 2014 UK [[YouGov]] poll, 46 percent of British people thought that newspapers reporting on the materials given to them by Snowden was good for society, while 22 percent thought it was bad for society and 31 percent didn't know.<ref name=YouGovUK>{{cite web |title=Snowden revelations 'good for society' |url=http://yougov.co.uk/news/2014/04/18/reporting-nsa-revelations-good-society/ |accessdate=April 24, 2014}}</ref>
==Media== On January 1, 2014, the editorial board of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised Snowden as a whistleblower and wrote in favor of granting him clemency, arguing that while Snowden may have broken the law, he had "done his country a great service" by bringing the abuses of the NSA to light. "When someone reveals that government officials have routinely and deliberately broken the law," they wrote, "that person should not face life in prison at the hands of the same government." ''The Times'' cast doubt on the claim made by Snowden's critics that he had damaged national security, and concluded with a request to President Obama to discontinue the "vilification" of Snowden and to give him "an incentive to return home."<ref name=NYTWhistleblower>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/02/opinion/edward-snowden-whistle-blower.html |title=Edward Snowden, Whistle-Blower |author=Editorial Board of ''The New York Times'' |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/columnist/rieder/2014/01/02/does-edward-snowden-deserve-clemency/4288535/ |title=Rieder: Why Edward Snowden should get clemency |work=USA Today |date=January 2, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref> The article garnered an unusual amount of blowback for an editorial, with responses from multiple media outlets.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/02/weeks-in-the-making-an-editorial-on-snowden-may-go-beyond-what-is-realistic/ |work=The New York Times |first=Margaret |last=Sullivan |title=Weeks in the Making, an Editorial on Snowden May Go ‘Beyond What Is Realistic' |date=January 2, 2014}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' called for a pardon in an editorial coincidentally published the same day, saying Snowden should be allowed to return home with dignity.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/01/snowden-affair-case-for-pardon-editorial |title=Snowden affair: the case for a pardon |work=The Guardian |date=May 17, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Satter |first=Raphael |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2-newspapers-calls-clemency-edward-snowden |title=2 newspapers call for clemency for Edward Snowden |work=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106091023/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2-newspapers-calls-clemency-edward-snowden |archivedate=January 6, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In a January 4, 2014 article, [[Peter Baker (author)|Peter Baker]] of ''The New York Times'' laid out the polarization of opinions throughout the U.S. and the impetus toward clemency gained by public reaction to Snowden's revelations. Yet despite a growing backlash against government surveillance, Baker noted, calls for leniency had made little headway in the White House, Justice Department, or national security establishment.<ref>Baker, Peter, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/05/us/moves-to-curb-spying-help-drive-the-clemency-argument-for-snowden.html?pagewanted=1&_r=0&nl=todaysheadlines&emc=edit_th_20140105 Moves to Curb Spying Help Drive the Clemency Argument for Snowden]," ''The New York Times'', January 5, 2014, page A16</ref>
In September 2016, the editorial board of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' characterized the issue of whether Snowden deserved a presidential pardon as "a complicated question" to which the president's answer should be "no".<ref name="No Pardon">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/edward-snowden-doesnt-deserve-a-pardon/2016/09/17/ec04d448-7c2e-11e6-ac8e-cf8e0dd91dc7_story.html |title=No pardon for Edward Snowden |author=''Washington Post'' Editorial Board |date=September 17, 2016 |newspaper=The Washington Post |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> The editors of the ''Post'' credited Snowden for "necessary reforms" brought about by his revelations of ''en masse'' collection of telephone data by the NSA, but stressed Snowden's separate leak of information about the agency's [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program and other "basically defensible" intelligence operations as reasons why he should face trial, saying that Snowden hurt his credibility as "an avatar of freedom" by accepting asylum in Russia.<ref name="No Pardon"/> The editors of the ''Post'' dismissed calls from human-rights organizations for clemency because of Snowden's "noble purposes" and the policy changes resulting from the leaks, and urged the president not to pardon Snowden despite the ''Post'' itself being responsible for publishing some of the leaked material.<ref name="Post says">{{cite news |author=Greenslade, Roy |date=September 19, 2016 |title=Washington Post says Obama should not pardon whistleblower Ed Snowden |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2016/sep/19/washington-post-says-obama-should-not-pardon-whistleblower-ed-snowden}}</ref> According to ''The Guardian'', the editorial stunned many American journalists.<ref name="Post says"/> Glenn Greenwald, one of the journalists to whom Snowden had initially leaked the classified documents, characterized the ''Post'' editorial as "an act of journalistic treachery" and "cowardice", noting that the ''Post'' had accepted a [[Pulitzer Prize for Public Service|Pulitzer Prize]] for publishing Snowden's leaks concerning PRISM and the other operations mentioned in its editorial.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2016/09/18/washpost-makes-history-first-paper-to-call-for-prosecution-of-its-own-source-after-accepting-pulitzer/ |title=WashPost Makes History: First Paper to Call for Prosecution of Its Own Source (After Accepting Pulitzer) |last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |date=September 18, 2016 |website=The Intercept}}</ref>
==Non-governmental organizations== [[File:Navanethem Pillay.jpg|thumb|[[Navi Pillay]], the United Nations' [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]], said: "Without prejudging the validity of any asylum claim by Snowden, I appeal to all States to respect the internationally guaranteed [[Right of asylum|right to seek asylum]]."<ref name="unitednationshr"/>]] After [[Amnesty International]] met Edward Snowden in Moscow in mid July 2013, the organization said:
<blockquote>What he has disclosed is patently in the public interest and as a whistleblower his actions were justified. He has exposed unlawful sweeping surveillance programmes that unquestionably interfere with an individual’s right to privacy. States that attempt to stop a person from revealing such unlawful behaviour are flouting international law. [[Freedom of expression]] is a fundamental right.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/amnesty-international-meets-us-whistleblower-edward-snowden-2013-07-12 Amnesty International meets US whistleblower Edward Snowden] July 12, 2013</ref></blockquote>
Widney Brown, Senior Director of Amnesty, feared that Snowden would be at "great risk" of human rights violations if forcibly transferred to the United States,<ref>{{cite web|title=USA must not hunt down whistleblower Edward Snowden|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/usa-must-not-hunt-down-whistleblower-edward-snowden-2013-06-24|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|accessdate=June 25, 2013}}</ref> and urged no country to return Snowden to the US. Michael Bochenek, Director of Law and Policy at Amnesty International deplored the US pressure on governments to block Snowden's asylum attempts, saying "It is his unassailable right, enshrined in international law".<ref name="amnesty1">[https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/usa-must-not-persecute-whistleblower-edward-snowden-2013-07-02 USA must not persecute whistleblower Edward Snowden] July 2, 2013 Amnesty</ref>
[[Human Rights Watch]] said that if Snowden were able to raise the issue of NSA [[mass surveillance]] without facing espionage charges, he would not have left the United States in the first place.<ref>{{cite web|title=US: Protect National Security Whistleblowers|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/06/18/us-protect-national-security-whistleblowers|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|accessdate=June 25, 2013}}</ref> Human Rights Watch writes that any country where Snowden seeks asylum should consider his claim fairly and protect his rights under international law, which recognizes that revealing official secrets is sometimes justified in the public interest.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/07/03/countries-should-consider-snowden-s-asylum-claim-fairly Countries Should Consider Snowden’s Asylum Claim Fairly"]. Human Rights Watch, July 2013</ref>
[[Navi Pillay]], the United Nations [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]], said: "Snowden's case has shown the need to protect persons disclosing information on matters that have implications for human rights, as well as the importance of ensuring respect for the right to privacy".<ref name="unitednationshr">{{cite web|title=UN rights chief urges protection for individuals revealing human rights violations|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?Cr=asylum&NewsID=45399#.Uf7eH6y_S28|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=August 4, 2013}}</ref>
[[Transparency International]], International Association of Lawyers against Nuclear Arms and [[Vereinigung Deutscher Wissenschaftler]] awarded Snowden the German Whistleblowerpreis 2013.<ref name="heise-1922132">{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Whistleblower-Preis-fuer-Edward-Snowden-1922132.html |title=Whistleblower-Preis für Edward Snowden |accessdate=July 25, 2013 |author=''Heise Online''-Autoren Detlef Borchers, anw |date=July 23, 2013 |work=Heise Online |archivedate=July 25, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IMvcdV8q?url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Whistleblower-Preis-fuer-Edward-Snowden-1922132.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The [[Humanist Union]] awarded him the [[Fritz Bauer Prize]] 2013.<ref name="hpd-16474">{{cite web|url=http://hpd.de/node/16474 |title=Fritz-Bauer-Preis an Edward Snowden |accessdate=July 25, 2013 |author=Sven Lüders |date=July 24, 2013 |work=Humanistischer Pressedienst |archivedate=July 25, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IMvQXUEU?url=http://hpd.de/node/16474 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== Whistleblowers === [[Daniel Ellsberg]], the whistleblower and leaker of the top-secret [[Pentagon Papers]] in 1971, stated in an interview with CNN that he thought Snowden had done an "incalculable" service to his country and that his leaks might prevent the United States from becoming a surveillance state. He said Snowden had acted with the same sort of courage and patriotism as a soldier in battle.<ref>{{cite news |last=O'Malley |first=Nick |title=NSA leaker reveals himself after fleeing US |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=June 10, 2013 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/nsa-leaker-reveals-himself-after-fleeing-us-20130610-2nz6h.html |accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> In an op-ed the following morning, Ellsberg added that "there has not been in American history a more important leak than Edward Snowden's release of NSA material ... including the Pentagon Papers."<ref name="ellsbergstasi">{{cite news |last=Ellsberg |first=Daniel |title=Edward Snowden: saving us from the United Stasi of America |work=The Guardian |date=June 10, 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/10/edward-snowden-united-stasi-america |accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> [[Ray McGovern]], a retired CIA officer turned political activist, agreed with Ellsberg and added, "This time today I'm feeling much more hopeful for our democracy than I was feeling this time yesterday."<ref>{{cite news |last=Noor |first=Jaisal |title=Former CIA Analyst: Snowden Did The Right Thing |newspaper=The Real News Network |date=June 11, 2013 |url=http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=74&jumival=10297}}</ref>
[[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]], a whistleblower who disclosed details of the NSA's mass surveillance activities, said that Snowden had "performed a really great public service to begin with by exposing these programs and making the government in a sense publicly accountable for what they're doing." After Snowden cited a conversation with a "reliable source" about allegations that the US was "hacking into China", Binney felt he was "transitioning from whistle-blower to a traitor."<ref name="usatoday1">Eisler, Peter; Page, Susan (June 16, 2013). "[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/06/16/snowden-whistleblower-nsa-officials-roundtable/2428809/ 3 NSA veterans speak out on whistle-blower: We told you so]." ''USA Today'' (Washington DC). Retrieved June 19, 2013.</ref>
[[Thomas Andrews Drake|Thomas Drake]], former senior executive of NSA and whistleblower, said that he feels "extraordinary kinship" with Snowden. "What he did was a magnificent act of civil disobedience. He's exposing the inner workings of the surveillance state. And it's in the public interest. It truly is."<ref name="usatoday1"/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/12/snowden-surveillance-subverting-constitution Snowden saw what I saw: surveillance criminally subverting the constitution] ''The Guardian''. Retrieved July 10, 2013</ref>
[[WikiLeaks]] founder [[Julian Assange]] hailed Snowden as a "hero" who has exposed "one of the most serious events of the decade – the creeping formulation of a mass surveillance state."<ref>{{cite news |last=Addley |first=Esther |title=Julian Assange praises Edward Snowden as a hero |newspaper=The Guardian |date=June 10, 2013 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/jun/10/julian-assange-praises-edward-snowden |accessdate= June 10, 2013 |location= London}}</ref> After charges against Snowden were revealed, Assange released a statement asking people to "step forward and stand with" Snowden.<ref>Dart, Tom (June 22, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/22/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-julian-assange "Support NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden, says Julian Assange"]. ''The Guardian'' (London). Retrieved June 22, 2013.</ref> Following President Obama's assurances that changes are planned for the NSA surveillance program, Assange said in a written statement that Obama had "validated Edward Snowden's role as a whistle-blower".<ref>{{cite web|author=David Jackson |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/theoval/2013/08/11/obama-snowden-assange-nsa-surveillance/2640217/ |title=Assange: Obama 'validates' Snowden |work=USA Today }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/10/us-usa-surveillance-assange-idUSBRE9790A920130810 |title=Assange calls Obama reform plans 'victory of sorts' for Snowden |agency=Reuters |date=August 10, 2013}}</ref>
[[Shamai Leibowitz]], who leaked details about an FBI operation, said that the legal threats and "smear campaign" against Snowden are a "grave mistake" because "If the government really wanted to keep more secrets from coming out, they would do well to let this man of conscience go live his life in some other country."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/05/blowback-white-house-whistleblowers Blowback from the White House's vindictive war on whistleblowers]." [[Shamai Leibowitz|Leibowitz, Shamai]] in ''[[The Guardian]]''. July 5, 2013. Retrieved July 5, 2013.</ref>
In October 2013, four US whistleblowers and activists visited Moscow to present Snowden with an award for truth-telling titled [[Sam Adams Award|The Sam Adams Award for Integrity in Intelligence]].<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/snowdens-father-arrives-in-moscow/2013/10/10/ec4f6c32-3182-11e3-ad00-ec4c6b31cbed_story_1.html The Washington Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.whistleblower.org/blog/44-2013/3012-former-national-security-whistleblowers-meet-in-moscow-and-award-sam-adams-prize-to-snowden- Former National Security Whistleblowers Meet in Moscow and Award Sam Adams Prize to Snowden - Government Accountability Project<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226231127/http://www.whistleblower.org/blog/44-2013/3012-former-national-security-whistleblowers-meet-in-moscow-and-award-sam-adams-prize-to-snowden- |date=2013-12-26 }}</ref> Thomas Drake, one of the presenters, told reporters after the event that the US had "unchained itself from their own constitution" by banning the "real law and [using] a secret law and secret interpretations of law." He further explained that Snowden "had to escape the US to ensure any chance of freedom", claiming the US had made Snowden stateless by revoking his passport while in Russia, leading to his temporary asylum in the country. Drake praised Russia, saying it had "actually recognized the international law and granted him political asylum".<ref>[http://rt.com/news/rt-whistleblowers-snowden-prize-983/ 'US unchained itself from constitution': Whistleblowers on RT after secret Snowden meeting — RT News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Possas, PhD - in Tamara's office.jpg | image_size = | caption = Cristina Possas, PhD | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1948|6|5}} | birth_place = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = *[[Harvard School of Public Health]], Post-doctoral work in International Health *[[Fiocruz]], National School of Public Health, PhD in Public Health, 1988 *[[UNICAMP]], Master’s Degree in Social Sciences, 1980 *[[PUC-Rio]], Doctoral Degree in Psychology, 1972 | occupation = [[Ministry of Health (Brazil)|Minister of health]], [[public health]] research scientist, [[infectious disease]] research scientist, academic | years_active = 1985 — present | nationality = [[Brazil]]ian | ethnicity = | citizenship = [[Brazil]] | residence = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] | known_for = [[social epidemiology]], [[Medical research]],
[[public health]],
[[infectious disease]],
[[Emerging infectious disease]] | networth = | home_town = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] | title = Professor
[[Fiocruz]] |religion = }} '''Cristina Possas de Albuquerque''' (born 5 June 1948) is a [[Brazilians|Brazilian]] [[public health]] scientist working with [[infectious diseases]] and [[emerging infectious disease]]s from an [[Ecosocial theory|eco-social]] perspective.Krieger, N., "Epidemiology and the web of causation: has anyone seen the spider?" Social Science and Medicine 1994; 39:887–903Krieger, Nancy (2011). Epidemiology and the People's Health : Theory and Context. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|9780199750351}}. However, her approach to social ecosystem complexity is quite different from the four-fold eco-social approach of Harvard's Nancy Krieger in that she has proposed in a 2001 English-language article in the ''Brazilian Journal of Public Health Reports'' the concept of "social ecosystem health" where ecosystems are increasingly changed by social human activity, favoring the emergence of diseases, so the term "social" should precede the prefix "eco".Possas, C. 2001. Social ecosystem health: confronting the complexity and emergence of infectious diseases. Cadernos de Saúde Pública (Brazilian Journal pf Public Health Reports) 17.1: 30-41.Possas, C. 2001 Debate on the paper by David Waltner-Toews. Cadernos de Saúde Pública (''Brazilian Journal pf Public Health Reports''), 17, S27-S28. Levins, R. and Lopez C. "Toward an ecosocial view of health", ''International Journal of Health Services'' 29(2):261-293, 1999. Her mentor and former colleague, Dr. [[Richard Levins]], had used the phrase "ecosocial view of health." Thus, she is known for (a) developing her new conceptual approach to [[social epidemiology]], incorporating the economic concept of structural heterogeneity into an epidemiological model to identify the epidemiological profiles of heterogeneous populations in different social and economic strata and the conditions for emergence of diseases; (b) contributions of health policy and health reform in Brazil; and research on health transition, ecological change, complex systems, and emergence of new diseases. She is a Takemi Fellow at Harvard University in Boston,[http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/fellowships/takemi-fellowship-program/ Takemi Program], [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]][http://ems.sph.harvard.edu/MasterCalendar/EventDetails.aspx?data=hHr80o3M7J5dSU1l%2F%2FAreV7Jd9fcjcVoCH%2BPlrX4uXxoT57ypPvhl%2BVQWaGVjPQ0 Cristina Possas: Zika and Dengue in Brazil: ecological, social, and anthropological perspectives] where for 10 years she has been a Visiting Scientist and a [[Fulbright Fellowship|Fulbright Fellow]], and a professor at [[FIOCRUZ]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil.[http://www.sigass.fiocruz.br/pub/programa/docente/espelho.do?codDados=37252 FIOCRUZ Faculty profile for Cristina de Albuquerque Possas, PhD] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308061641/http://www.sigass.fiocruz.br/pub/programa/docente/espelho.do?codDados=37252 |date=2016-03-08 }} ==Career== {{further|Health in Brazil|Ministry of Health (Brazil)}} [[Image:Manguinhos_fiocruz2.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Façade of the [[Moorish Revival|Neo-Mouresque]] Palace of Manguinhos, seat of the Instituto Oswaldo Cruz in Rio de Janeiro.]] As a Brazilian Brazilian [[public health]] scientist working with [[infectious diseases]] from an [[Ecosocial theory|eco-social]] perspective, Cristina Possas de Albuquerque (Cristina Possas) has as a policymaker long worked closely with public health and environmental scientists and with human rights and social justice civil organizations. She also is a full professor at [[FIOCRUZ]] in Brazil, where in 1998 she had earned a PhD in [[public health]], and where she now does research on infectious diseases and teaches a course named "Scientific Methodology" in the Masters and Doctoral Programs. She has been also a Professor of Health Policy at the National School of Public Health at the [[Oswaldo Cruz Foundation]], Brazil. She was nominated in 1987 by the Brazilian Ministry of Health/Fiocruz to be the National Technical Coordinator of seven Groups supporting the Health Reform in Brazil, whose contributions were later incorporated into the new Brazilian 1988 Constitution. For a decade, she also has been a Takemi Fellow at Harvard University, a Visiting Scientist and [[Fulbright Fellowship|Fulbright Fellow]], and a member of the Harvard New Diseases Group, coordinated by the late [[Richard Levins]] and by [[Tamara Awerbuch-Friedlander]], collaborating with them and other outstanding members of the group in the organizing committee of the Woods Hole Conference on New Diseases, with articles with the group later published in a special supplement of the ''Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences'' on this conference and in other journals. She had held for 10 years a national position as the Head of the Research and Development Unit of the Brazilian National AIDS Program. She has worked for more than five decades in several national and international positions with the scientific community and civil society organizations. For ten years, she had been National Director of the Research and Technological Development Unit at the Brazilian [[AIDS]] Program in the Brazilian Ministry of Health, which has been recognized globally as an outstanding public health initiative with innovative approaches to the pandemics, always centering on free and universal access to prevention and treatment. She was invited by the Director of the National AIDS Program to conceive and create a new and innovative Research and Technological Development Unit in the Program’s structure. She has given interviews on [[AIDS]],[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZqG-W1Xyoac Entrevista, Dr. Cristina Possas discusses AIDS, Dec 16, 2015] [[dengue fever|dengue]], and [[zika fever|zika]]. ==Recent experience== * Full professor, [[FIOCRUZ]] ([[Oswaldo Cruz Foundation]]/Instituto Oswaldo Cruz), [[Brazil]], 1985–present : Coordinated Master’s, Doctoral, and Post-Doctoral Programs in Public Health and Clinical Research on Infectious Diseases. * Director, Research and Technological Development Unit, National AIDS Program, [[Ministry of Health (Brazil)|Ministry of Health]], [[Brazil]], 2002–2011 * National Executive Secretary, National Technical Biosafety Commission (CTNBio), Ministry of Science and Technology, Brazil, 2001–2002 * Visiting Scientist, New Diseases Group, [[Harvard School of Public Health]], 1994–2002 * Takemi Fellow in International Health, [[Harvard School of Public Health]], 1990–1994 * [[Fulbright Fellow]], [[Harvard University]], 1990-1994 ==Appointments== '''FIOCRUZ''' 1985–present - Full professor and researcher at [[FIOCRUZ]] (Master, Doctoral and Post-Doctoral Programs in Clinical Research on Infectious Diseases).
